text: Harry Betmead (11 April 1912 – 26 August 1984) was an English footballer who played for Grimsby Town, as well as the English national side. He also played cricket for Lincolnshire.Cricket archive He spent his entire 17-year career with Grimsby, from 1930 to 1947, and is one of only three players to win an England cap whilst at the club (the other two being teammates Jackie Bestall and George Tweedy). He helped the club to win the Second Division title in 1933–34 and to reach two FA Cup semi-finals. After retiring from the game he went into business in Hertfordshire. ==Club career== Born in Grimsby, Betmead was playing for local side Hay Cross when he was signed for Grimsby Town by Wilf Gillow in October 1930 aged 18 years old. He made his debut almost a year later on 15 September 1931 against Bolton Wanderers. He quickly established himself as one of the first names on the "Mariners" team sheet, and remained at the club for the whole of his career, despite considerable interest from bigger cubs. Grimsby suffered relegation out of the First Division in 1931–32, before finishing 13th in the Second Division in 1932–33. They won promotion as the division's champions in 1933–34. Town finished fifth in 1934–35. They dropped to 17th place in 1935–36, though reached the semi-finals of the FA Cup, where they were beaten 1–0 by Arsenal. The Blundell Park outfit then posted 12th, 20th, and 10th-place finishes in 1936–37, 1937–38, and 1938–39. They also reached the semi-finals of the FA Cup again in 1939, this time losing out 5–0 to Wolverhampton Wanderers at Old Trafford. During the war he became a physical training instructor in the army, also guesting for Heart of Midlothian, Aldershot, Chesterfield and Port Vale. He also managed to play 40 games and score five goals for Grimsby in the war years. After normal football resumed, Betmead helped the club to post a 16th-place finish in the top-flight in 1946–47. He retired in December 1947. He had scored ten goals in 296 league appearances for the club. ==International career== Called up to the England squad, he played in the 8–0 win over Finland in Helsinki on 20 May 1937.Player profile at EnglandStats.comPlayer profile at EnglandFC.com Betmead toured South Africa with an English FA side in 1939 and was captain in two of the unofficial internationals against the full South Africa team.RSSSF.com SA Tour Details ==Style of play== Betmead played at centre-half; he was a strong tackler and had excellent aerial ability. ==Statistics== Source: {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |- !rowspan="2"|Club !rowspan="2"|Season !rowspan="2"|Division !colspan="2"|League !colspan="2"|FA Cup !colspan="2"|Total |- !Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals |- |rowspan="9"|Grimsby Town |1931–32 |First Division |17||2||0||0||17||2 |- |1932–33 |Second Division |30||2||2||0||32||2 |- |1933–34 |Second Division |42||0||2||0||44||0 |- |1934–35 |First Division |26||1||0||0||26||1 |- |1935–36 |First Division |35||0||5||0||40||0 |- |1936–37 |First Division |38||1||2||0||40||1 |- |1937–38 |First Division |38||1||1||0||39||1 |- |1938–39 |First Division |36||3||7||0||43||3 |- |1946–47 |First Division |34||0||0||0||34||0 |- !colspan="3"|Career total !296!!10!!19!!0!!315!!10 |} ==References== Category:1912 births Category:1984 deaths Category:Sportspeople from Grimsby Category:English footballers Category:Association football defenders Category:England international footballers Category:Grimsby Town F.C. players Category:Heart of Midlothian F.C. wartime guest players Category:Aldershot F.C. wartime guest players Category:Chesterfield F.C. wartime guest players Category:Port Vale F.C. wartime guest players Category:English Football League players Category:English cricketers Category:Lincolnshire cricketers
